results.title: Birth of a Florida key
results.brief_description: The origin and growth of the Islets making up the Florida Keys is explained. Mangrove bushes grow with amazing rapidity providing shelter to sea-birds, and assisting in the formation of marine life such as crabs, lobsters, and shell fish, all of which play their part in stabilising the growing islet. Rain helps reduce the salty content of the substratum until it is able to support other forms of plant life besides mangroves. Eventually insects and reptiles are soon represented and the ecological history of the island is complete.

results.title: Birth in the squatting position
results.brief_description: This film shows and discusses the method of giving birth in the squatting position as used in India. Such a position plays a significant role in facilitating labour and delivery, reducing neurological complications in the neonate resulting from birth trauma and in fostering initial maternal-infant attachment. No other credits available.

results.title: Birth control - How?
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, Ted Yates, Stuart Schulberg and Frank Slinglarn
results.brief_description: Discusses “the pill” and other birth control methods, and describes controlled experiment groups in Kentucky and in Puerto Rico. Examines some of the moral dimensions of birth control.

results.title: Birth and death of mountains
results.creator_credit: BFA Educational Media, Film Associates and Paul Burnford
results.brief_description: Shows the forces that wear down mountains and those that cause mountains to be formed. Uses drawings to demonstrate formations of fold mountains, new faultblock mountains and new dome mountains. Observes the mountain-flattening forces of glaciers, wind and water. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Birds that never fly
results.creator_credit: Bank of New South Wales and Harold J. Pollock
results.brief_description: This film deals with the flightless birds of Australia and New Zealand: the emu, cassowary, kiwi and the extinct moa. It shows their physical characteristics, breeding and eating habits. Narrated by John Dease. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Birds that eat insects
results.brief_description: Explains how the physical structure of birds is adapted to the kind of food they eat. Draws attention to the strong wings and wide bills of birds that chase insects in the air; the small size and agility of birds that hunt in bushes; and the strong chisel-shaped bill of wood-peckers. Shows the swallow, nighthawk, kingbird chestnut -sided warbler, black-billed cuckoo, white-breasted nuthatch, flicker, robin, bluebird, housewren, and hairy, downy and redheaded woodpeckers. No other credits available.

results.title: Birds that eat flesh
results.brief_description: Explains how the physical structure of birds is adapted to the food they eat. Shows members of the hawk family, which hunt by day, and calls attention to their strong wings, talons, and sharp hooked bill. Shows night hunters which have the sharp hooked bill and powerful large talons of the hawks. Explains that they rely on keen night vision and sensitive hearing to locate prey, and draws attention to the soft downy feathers on wing tips which make flight noiseless. No other credits available.

results.title: Birds that eat fish
results.brief_description: Explains how the physical structure of birds is adapted to the kind of food they eat. Draws attention to the long sharp bill, long toes and legs to support wading birds like the heron, the strong sharp pointed bill of the kingfisher which plunges into water to seize fish in its beak, the strong wings, legs, and talons of the osprey which glides in the air then drops into water to seize fish in its talons.
